title: AI system
definition: A machine-based system that is designed to operate with varying levels of autonomy and that may exhibit adaptiveness after deployment, and that, for explicit or implicit objectives, infers, from the input it receives, how to generate outputs such as predictions, content, recommendations, or decisions that can influence physical or virtual environments

elements.text: designed to operate with varying levels of autonomy
elements.flag: LOW_CONFIDENCE: 'varying levels of autonomy' - spectrum includes fully automated to human-in-the-loop. What minimum autonomy threshold?

elements.interpretation: Includes both adaptive and non-adaptive systems

elements.text: infers, from the input it receives, how to generate outputs
elements.note: 'Infers' suggests some form of computation/processing beyond pure rule execution
elements.flag: MEDIUM_CONFIDENCE: Does simple if-then logic constitute 'inference'? Or requires statistical/ML inference?
elements.critical_question: Boundary between traditional software and AI system unclear

elements.text: outputs such as predictions, content, recommendations, or decisions
can influence physical or virtual environments
elements.flag: MEDIUM_CONFIDENCE: 'can influence' - potential vs. actual influence? Trivial vs. material influence?
elements.note: Very broad - almost all software influences virtual environments

critical_interpretative_questions: What distinguishes AI system from traditional algorithmic software?
What minimum level of autonomy required?
How to handle edge cases: calculators, compilers, database queries?

confidence_assessment.practical_application: MEDIUM - will require case-by-case LLM evaluation for edge cases
